meaning: The law stating that no atoms are lost or made during a chemical reaction
The mass of a compound relative to a proton or neutron
The mass of an element relative to a proton or neutron
The unit used for chemical amounts, where one mole of a substance in grams is numerically equal to its relative formula mass
The number of atoms, ions or molecules in a mole of a substance. It has a value of 6.02 x 10²³ per mole
The reactant in a reaction that is completely used up and limits the amount of product formed
The mass per unit volume of solution, measured in mol/dm³ or g/dm³.
The percentage of the theoretical product that is actually formed
A measure of the amount of starting material that ends up as the desired product
The amount of product actually produced by a reaction
The amount of product that could be produced if the reaction goes perfectly.
The interval in which the true value can be expected to lie.
